ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Advanced immunology and some promising areas.
Good course for thinking critically about research. Shifting the focus to building models and seeing how the evidence fit was a good method to reinforce.
I enjoyed learning how to present my own ideas in animated debate and discussion on these topics.
Dry interesting to have faculty members teach from primary literature and reviews of different areas of immunology
Fundamental knowledge of a broad array of immunology topics.
knowledge in several specific topic in the field of immunology, critical thinking and speculation of unknown question.
Better critical thinking skills in the field, greater familiarity with subfields and research questions, practice in thinking about/designing experiments.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Very good class to know advanced immunology and very good discussion on the class.
Strength of the course is the focus on "big picture" view of important topics.

Strengths: The focus on unanswered questions in immunology was interesting and useful. Most of the faculty instructors were well prepared and selected papers that were interesting and thought provoking. Weaknesses: I was not interested in some of the topics selected. Some faculty were also better than others in stimulating discussion. Although we received a score from each professor (I believe based on the written response as well as for class discussion), we received virtually no feedback on the specifics of our responses to questions. This is probably my least favorite aspect of graduate school, and my most common criticism for all of the courses I have taken so far. We do spend time writing responses or papers but are almost always only given a score, which really doesn't matter (at least to me). If the faculty took time to make specific comments, criticisms, or suggestions for improvement (even if these comments were only brief, I do understand that the faculty are busy) then I think I would learn more.
Discussion was more lively when there were discussion questions we could refer to rather than going over papers one by one
Good selection and organization of course topics. May have been a little heavy on microbiota, but otherwise good.
Usually engaging discussion. Interesting topics. Most faculty were good at leading discussion, but a few could have been better at fostering discussion (some faculty cut off students)

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Very good class to know advanced immunology and very good discussion on the class.
Nice opportunity to hear from faculty their thought process when approaching these topics.

Yes: I found the discussions (on the whole) to be helpful and informative. The course's focus on unanswered questions was the strongest point of the class, and this type of course seems rare (i.e. most courses focus on learning something that is already known). I also found the discussions which centered around an unexpected immunological finding to be the most interesting and thought provoking. By 'unexpected,' I mean a finding that would not necessarily have been predicted based only on the principles taught in the introductory course. I did enjoy the class and this was probably my favorite class I have taken in graduate school so far, but (as I mentioned above) I do think there should be some feedback other than just a grade.
Yes. It is a great chance to interact with diverse faculty.

great opportunity to build skills and knowledge base of immuno. interesting subject matter. reading + 1 single-spaced page/week writing requirement, which required more time than my other classes. overall worth it, feel like a more competent immunobiologist after taking this class.
